text:
You're travelling in very heavy rain. How is this likely to affect your overall 
stopping distance?

options.B: It will be doubled
options.C: It will be halved
options.D: It will be ten times greater

explanation: It will be doubled. In heavy rain, stopping distances can double due to reduced tyre grip on wet surfaces.

text:
What should you do when
you're overtaking at night?

options.A: Go past slowly so that you can react to unseen hazards
options.B: Beware of bends in the road ahead
options.C: Wait until a bend so that you can see oncoming headlights
options.D: Sound your horn twice before moving out

explanation: Increase your distance from the vehicle in front. Extra space gives you more time to react and stop safely on slippery surfaces.

text:
When may you wait in a
box junction?

options.A: When you're stationary in a queue of traffic
options.B: When oncoming traffic prevents you turning right
options.C: When approaching a zebra crossing

explanation: Slow down gently. Engine braking by lifting off the accelerator gently helps reduce speed without skidding on ice.

text:
What's the reason for
traffic-calming measures?

options.B: To make parking easier
options.C: To slow traffic down

explanation: Increase. Wet roads reduce tyre grip, significantly increasing the distance needed to stop.

text:
What colour are the 
reflective studs along the left-hand edge of the 
motorway?

options.B: Red
options.C: White

explanation: Twice the normal distance. On icy roads, you can need up to ten times the stopping distance, so doubling following distance is minimum.

text:
What's a rumble device
designed to do?

options.B: Alert you to low tyre pressure
options.C: Prevent cattle escaping

explanation: Reduce your speed. Tyres need good tread to disperse water; with worn treads, you must drive more carefully.

text:
What should you do if you
have to make a journey in
foggy conditions?

options.A: Leave plenty of time for your journey
options.B: Keep two seconds behind the vehicle ahead
options.C: Follow other vehicles’ tail lights closely

explanation: Steer into the skid. Steering in the direction the rear of the car is sliding helps straighten the vehicle.

text:
What must you do when
you're overtaking a car at
night?

options.B: Flash your headlights before overtaking
options.C: Make sure you don't dazzle other road users
options.D: Switch your headlights to main beam before overtaking

explanation: Keep steady pressure on the brake pedal. ABS works best with firm, steady pressure - don't pump the brakes.

text:
You're travelling on a road that has road humps. What should you do when the driver in front is 
travelling more slowly than you?

options.B: Sound your horn
options.C: Overtake as soon as you can

explanation: Use the highest gear you can. Higher gears provide gentler power delivery, reducing wheel spin on snow.

text:
What’s the purpose of
the yellow lines painted
across the road?

options.A: To keep the area clear of traffic
options.B: To make you aware of your speed
options.C: To show a safe distance between vehicles
options.D: To warn you to change direction

explanation: Drive at a slow speed in a low gear. Low gears give better control through water, and slow speed reduces spray and aquaplaning risk.

text:
What should you do
when you meet an oncoming
vehicle on a single-track
road?

options.B: Reverse back to the main road
options.C: Switch on your hazard warning lights

explanation: Gently apply the brakes while moving slowly. Test brakes carefully after driving through water to ensure they're working properly.

text:
The road is wet. Why
would a motorcyclist steer
around drain covers while
they were cornering?

options.A: To avoid splashing pedestrians on the pavement
options.B: To avoid puncturing the tyres on the edge of the drain covers
options.C: To help judge the bend using the drain covers as marker points
options.D: To prevent the motorcycle sliding on the metal drain covers

explanation: It will increase. Loose surfaces like gravel reduce tyre grip, increasing stopping distance.

text:
Why should you test
your brakes after this
hazard?

options.B: You'll be on a slippery road
options.C: You'll have just crossed a long bridge
options.D: You'll be going down a long hill

explanation: By selecting a low gear. Engine braking in a low gear helps control speed without relying solely on brakes.

text:
Why should you reduce
your speed when you're
driving or riding in fog?

options.A: The engine will take longer to warm up
options.B: You'll be dazzled by other headlights
options.C: The brakes don't work as well
options.D: It's more difficult to see what's ahead

explanation: Ease off the accelerator. Lifting off the accelerator uses engine braking to slow down without causing a skid.

text:
What will happen to your
car when you drive up a
steep hill?

options.B: The high gears will pull better
options.C: The steering will feel heavier

explanation: They'll lose grip on the road surface. When tyres lose contact with the road due to water, you lose all steering and braking control.

text:
You're driving on the 
motorway in windy 
conditions. What should you do as you overtake a high-sided vehicle?

options.B: Increase your speed
options.C: Be wary of a sudden gust

explanation: The brakes will be less effective. Water on brakes reduces friction, making them less effective until they dry out.

text:
You're driving in fog.
Why should you keep well
back from the vehicle in
front?

options.A: In case it changes direction suddenly
options.B: In case its brake lights dazzle you
options.C: In case it stops suddenly
options.D: In case its fog lights dazzle you

explanation: Use a low gear and drive slowly. Low gear gives better control, and slow speed reduces the risk of losing control on mud.

text:
What should you do if
you park on the road when
it's foggy?

options.B: Leave dipped headlights and fog lights switched on
options.C: Leave dipped headlights switched on

explanation: Oversteer. When the rear wheels lose grip before the front, the back of the car slides outward.

text:
You're driving at night.
What should you do if you're
dazzled by headlights
coming towards you?

options.B: Shade your eyes with your hand
options.C: Flash your main-beam headlights

explanation: Much greater. Icy conditions can increase stopping distance by up to 10 times normal distance.

text:
When may front fog
lights be used?

options.A: When an audible warning device is used
options.B: When they aren't as bright as the headlights
options.C: When they're fitted above the bumper

explanation: Release the accelerator. Lifting off the accelerator helps transfer weight to the front wheels and regain grip.

text:
You're driving with your
front fog lights switched on.
What should you do if the
fog has cleared?

options.A: Switch them off as long as visibility remains good
options.B: Leave them on if other drivers have their lights on
options.C: Drive with them on instead of your headlights
options.D: Flash them to warn oncoming traffic that it's foggy

explanation: In as high a gear as possible. Higher gears reduce the risk of wheel spin when pulling away on ice.

text:
Why should you switch
off your rear fog lights when
the fog has cleared?

options.A: To allow your headlights to work
options.B: To stop draining the battery
options.C: To stop the engine losing power

explanation: Avoid sudden steering movements. Smooth, gentle inputs help maintain control on slippery surfaces.

text:
What will happen if you
use rear fog lights in good
conditions?

options.A: They'll make it safer when towing a trailer
options.B: They'll make drivers behind keep back
options.C: They'll dazzle other drivers
options.D: They'll protect you from larger vehicles

explanation: Be ready to reduce your speed. In strong side winds, you may need to slow down to maintain control, especially when passing high-sided vehicles.

text:
Why would you fit chains
to your wheels?

options.A: To help prevent the brakes locking
options.B: To help prevent damage to the road surface
options.C: To help prevent wear to the tyres
options.D: To help prevent skidding in deep snow

explanation: Four times. At 40 mph your stopping distance is roughly four times greater than at 20 mph.

text:
How can you use your
vehicle's engine to control
your speed?

options.B: By changing to a lower gear
options.C: By selecting reverse gear
options.D: By changing to a higher gear

explanation: Slow down gradually. Reducing speed gently maintains control and doesn't risk a skid.

text:
Why could it be 
dangerous to keep the 
clutch down, or select 
neutral, for long periods of time while you're driving?

options.A: It will wear tyres out more quickly
options.B: You'll have less steering and braking control
options.C: Engine damage may be caused

explanation: Allow extra room. Strong winds can push cyclists off course, so give them extra space.

text:
You're driving on an icy
road. What distance from
the car in front should you
drive?

options.B: Ten times the normal distance
options.C: Eight times the normal distance

explanation: Steer into it. Steering into the skid helps realign the vehicle with the direction of travel.

text:
Which lights must you
use if you're driving on a
well-lit motorway at night?

options.B: Use front fog lights
options.C: Use rear fog lights

explanation: Release the footbrake. Releasing the brake can help regain steering control if wheels have locked.

text:
You're driving on a 
motorway at night. Which lights should you have on if there are other vehicles just ahead of you?

options.B: Main-beam headlights
options.C: Sidelights only

explanation: Be more cautious. Wet roads reduce grip significantly, requiring extra care in all maneuvers.

text:
What will affect your
vehicle's stopping distance?

options.B: The condition of the tyres
options.C: The time of day

explanation: Drive in a low gear with the clutch up. Engine braking helps control speed on steep descents without overheating brakes.

text:
When will you feel the
effects of engine braking?

options.A: When you change to a higher gear
options.B: When you only use the parking brake
options.C: When you're in neutral
options.D: When you change to a lower gear

explanation: Pump the brake pedal. Without ABS, pumping prevents wheel locking while maintaining some braking effect.

text:
Why are vehicles fitted
with rear fog lights?

options.A: To make them more visible when driving at high speed
options.B: To warn drivers following closely to drop back
options.C: To make them more visible in thick fog
options.D: To show when they've broken down in a dangerous position

explanation: They'll be less effective. Cold temperatures reduce tyre flexibility and grip on road surfaces.

text:
There's been a heavy fall
of snow. What should you
consider before driving in
these conditions?

options.B: Whether you should wear sunglasses to reduce the glare
options.C: Whether you should drive without wearing your seat belt
options.D: Whether you should fit an amber flashing beacon to your car

explanation: Slow down before you reach it. Reduce speed before entering a bend to maintain control throughout the turn.

text:
What should you check
before you start a journey in
foggy weather?

options.A: You have a warning triangle in the vehicle
options.B: The windows and lights are clean and clear
options.C: You have a mobile phone with you

explanation: A lower gear. Lower gears provide engine braking and better control on steep descents.

text:
You've been driving in
fog. What must you do when
the visibility improves?

options.A: Leave your fog lights switched on in case the fog returns
options.B: Keep your front fog lights switched on
options.C: Keep your rear fog lights switched on

explanation: Drive more slowly. Reduced visibility requires lower speeds to allow time to react to hazards.

text:
Why is it dangerous to
leave rear fog lights
switched on after the fog
has cleared?

options.A: Direction indicators may not work properly
options.B: They may be confused with brake lights
options.C: The bulbs would fail

explanation: Brake gently in plenty of time. Gentle, early braking reduces the risk of skidding on slippery surfaces.

text:
What will happen if you hold the clutch pedal down or roll in neutral for too 
long?

options.B: It will improve tyre wear
options.C: It will use more fuel
options.D: It will cause the engine to overheat

explanation: Brake firmly and quickly. ABS prevents wheel lock, so you can brake firmly without losing steering control.

text:
Why is it bad technique
to coast when you're driving
downhill?

options.B: The vehicle will gain speed more quickly
options.C: The tyres will wear more quickly

explanation: Ten times. Icy conditions can increase stopping distances by up to 10 times the normal distance.

text:
What should you do
when dealing with this
hazard?

options.B: Switch on your hazard warning lights
options.C: Use a high gear to prevent wheelspin
options.D: Use a low gear and drive slowly

explanation: Take care when cornering. Diesel spills make roads extremely slippery, especially affecting cornering grip.

text:
When must you use
dipped headlights during the
day?

options.B: When you're driving in poor visibility
options.C: When you're driving along narrow streets

explanation: The tyres will lift off the road surface. Aquaplaning occurs when water builds up between tyres and road, causing loss of contact.

text:
What should you do
when you're driving along a
road that has a series of
road humps?

options.B: Stay at a reduced speed for the whole stretch of road
options.C: Vary your speed between each road hump
options.D: Brake firmly when you reach each road hump

explanation: Drive at a reduced speed. Black ice is invisible and extremely slippery - slow down when conditions suggest it may be present.
